text.p: The Finnish markka was steady against the mark in early European trade after its entry into Europe's exchange rate mechanism (ERM) over the weekend.

Apart from an earlier brief sell-off which saw the markka weaken through 3.00 per mark, the Finnish currency was firm and steady at 2.9880/10, little changed from the 2.9870 level it traded at in late European trade on Friday.
"So far the reaction has been pretty calm except for a few blips out of Asia," said a Swedish bank dealer. "The view is that ERM will see (the markka) trade even steadier than before."
The markka joined the ERM on Saturday at a central rate of 3.04 per mark within 15 percent fluctuation bands.
Few were surprised at Finland's decision to join and there were scant misgivings about the central rate.
"It has always been high on the official agenda and it is seen safe in the current environment," said Roger Francis, senior analyst at IBJ International in London.

The 15 percent bands also give the markka a lot of leeway around the central rate but analysts expect the Bank of Finland to track a tighter band with some speculating on the 2.5 percent target range used by the Netherlands and Germany.
A Finnish central bank official said at the weekend that Finland intended to keep the markka within "relatively narrow" bands.
There has been some concern that the ERM link could harm the ability of Finland's key pulp and paper exporters to compete with neighbouring Sweden, still outside the ERM.
"On a European level, it would be political poison for Sweden to devalue or push for excessive depreciation and would certainly weaken Sweden's position within Europe," said IBJ's Francis.
Finland's ERM linkage has not changed Sweden's declared stance on its own entry into the mechanism or its possible membership of Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU).
Earlier today, Swedish finance minister Erik Asbrink reiterated Riksbank officials' comments at the weekend, saying pressure on Sweden to join ERM has not increased with Finland's decision to join.

"Finland is three to four quarters ahead of Sweden in economic development," said Keld Holm, interational economist at Lehman Brothers. "Finland has had a longer period of stability after overcoming the same problems Sweden encountered later."
The crown was steady against the mark, trading at 4.3070/00 at 1015 GMT against 4.3100/30 late Friday in Europe.

The mark was mostly steady on the other European currencies, taking Finland's ERM participation in its stride. With Finland in the ERM, focus is now on the re-entry of the Italian lira, expected by the end of this year.

"Once you get Italy in, then the pressure will be on Sweden and the UK to also join," said Michael Lewis, senior economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. "It looks like France and Germany are winning the argument that countries have to join ERM before EMU."
The mark was trading at 994.25/55 Italian lire at 1017 GMT, little changed from late Friday levels here of 994.80/5.15.
Against the French franc, the mark stood at 3.3854/59 against 3.3857/61 on Friday.
